results.abstract: New York Hall of Science's Rocket Park in Corona, Queens, reopens after its Atlas and Titan rockets were refurbished under $2 million project that began in 2001; former TV anchor Walter Cronkite and handful of astronauts and politicians attend official reopening; photo (M)/

headline.main: The Rocket Park Reopens, And Cronkite Reminisces

results.snippet: Walter Cronkite thought back to man's first landing on the moon at the reopening of Rocket Park at the Hall of Science in Queens.
results.lead_paragraph: Walter Cronkite leaned back in a folding chair yesterday in Corona, Queens, and squinted up at the 102-foot steel cylinder in front of him gleaming in the sun. ''There was nothing like the day we first landed on the moon,'' said the former anchor in the familiar warm baritone that narrated the first moon shots and became inseparable from the United States space program. ''It was the culmination of all we had been working on.''

results.abstract: Jon Caramanica interview with members of rock band Duran Duran, which has reunited almost twenty years after breaking up; group's new album Astronaut to be released this month; photos (M)

headline.main: They Loved The 80's Too, With Very Good Reason

results.snippet: In sessions free of rock-star burdens like record contracts or egos, Duran Duran recorded material for a comeback album, "Astronaut," to be released later this month.
results.lead_paragraph: THERE are things you don't forget about being a rock star. Sequestered for an interview in a private chamber at a posh hotel in downtown Manhattan, Simon LeBon motions for an assistant to come over. Pointing to his sparkling water, he says, with practiced derision: ''They made the ice with tap water -- I can taste the chlorine in it. Can you bring me another?'' Pause. ''With no ice?'' Moments later, the offending glass is replaced. Order, if it had ever been lost, is restored. There days, it's all coming back to him, along with the other members of Duran Duran, the band that once made them the crush objects of seemingly every adolescent girl on the planet. The group was one of the first success stories of the MTV era, five comely British lads with penchants for supermodel girlfriends, aggressive fashion and bombastic, synth-happy rock that wasn't afraid of disco sensuality. For three years, they topped American and British charts with indelibly catchy songs -- ''Rio,'' ''Hungry Like the Wolf'' and ''The Reflex'' -- puffy with lyrical ambiguity. Their second and third albums, ''Rio'' and ''Seven and the Ragged Tiger,'' went platinum within weeks of release and contained their biggest hits. Then, just as quickly as the band appeared, it dissolved. Various permutations of group members, some recording under the original name, would chart through the next decade, but they would never register as highly as the original crew.

results.abstract: Private rocket ship called SpaceShipOne shoots into space and wins $10 million Ansari X aviation prize for its creators; craft reaches record altitude of 368,000 feet, or 69.7 miles, blasting past 337,600-foot altitude it reached last week; combination of rocket and glider was designed by Burt Rutan and financed by billionaire Paul G Allen, founders of Mojave Aerospace Ventures; private race for space has captured popular imagination, with its promise of wresting dream of human space flight away from NASA, which some private space boosters see as bloated and sluggish government monopoly; prize, which required two flights in two weeks, will be paid by special 'hole-in-one' insruance policy, common method of financing prize contests in which insurance company essentially bets against success; premium for policy was paid by Anousheh Ansari, telecommunications entrepreneur and board member of X Prize Foundation; $10 million award amounts to less than half of Allen's investment in project; photo (M)

headline.main: Private Rocket Ship Earns $10 Million In New Space Race

results.snippet: A private rocket ship shot into space this morning and won a coveted $10 million aviation prize for its creators.     SpaceShipOne, the sleek combination of rocket and glider designed by Burt Rutan and financed by the billionaire Paul G. Allen,...
results.lead_paragraph: A private rocket ship shot into space this morning and won a coveted $10 million aviation prize for its creators. SpaceShipOne, the sleek combination of rocket and glider designed by Burt Rutan and financed by the billionaire Paul G. Allen, reached a record altitude of 368,000 feet, or 69.7 miles, blasting past the 337,600-foot altitude reached by the same ship last week.

results.snippet: 2 Americans Win Nobel Prize for Study of Smell  Dr. Richard Axel of Columbia University and Dr. Linda B. Buck of the University of Washington won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for solving the riddle of how people can smell 10,000 odors...
results.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region
results.lead_paragraph: 2 Americans Win Nobel Prize for Study of Smell Dr. Richard Axel of Columbia University and Dr. Linda B. Buck of the University of Washington won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for solving the riddle of how people can smell 10,000 odors and recall them. PAGE A18 Justices Weigh Sentencing On the first day of its term, the Supreme Court heard arguments on the constitutionality of sentencing guidelines that have been in effect for 17 years, leaving little doubt that the system would change. PAGE A14 By the Book: A $350 Review Kirkus Reviews, a sort of Consumer Reports for book publishing, is starting an online publication that will review a new book from any publisher for $350. PAGE E1 The Boys of Fall The road to the World Series begins today with playoff games matching the Dodgers and Cardinals, Red Sox and Angels and Twins and Yankees. PAGE D1 Pioneering Astronaut Dies Gordon Cooper, who flew the last Mercury mission and stayed aloft in a Gemini capsule long enough to demonstrate that a trip to the moon was feasible, was 77. PAGE B8 Bush Courts the Black Clergy In a departure from typical Republican presidential campaigns, the Bush campaign is making a serious push for the allegiance of African-American clergy members. It has found success among those who like the president's outspoken Christian faith, his support for church-based social programs and his opposition to same-sex marriage. PAGE A15

results.abstract: Gordon Cooper, astronaut who flew last of pioneering Mercury space missions and stayed aloft in Gemini capsule long enough to demonstrate that trip to moon was feasible, dies at age 77; photo (M)

headline.main: Gordon Cooper, Astronaut, Is Dead at 77

results.snippet: Mr. Cooper was the last Mercury astronaut and thus the last American astronaut to fly alone in space.
results.lead_paragraph: Gordon Cooper, the astronaut who flew the last of the pioneering Mercury space missions and stayed aloft in a Gemini capsule long enough to demonstrate that a trip to the moon was feasible, died Monday at his home in Ventura, Calif., NASA said. He was 77. He died of natural causes, Mitch Breese of the Ventura County medical examiner's office, was quoted by The Associated Press as saying.

results.snippet: An obituary of the astronaut Gordon Cooper yesterday credited him erroneously with two breakthroughs. He was not the first American to fly into space twice; that was Virgil I. Grissom. Nor was he the last American astronaut to fly alone in space; in...
results.lead_paragraph: An obituary of the astronaut Gordon Cooper yesterday credited him erroneously with two breakthroughs. He was not the first American to fly into space twice; that was Virgil I. Grissom. Nor was he the last American astronaut to fly alone in space; in the last week, Michael W. Melvill and Brian Binnie flew solo in SpaceShipOne, the privately financed rocket and glider. A picture caption about the seven original Mercury astronauts carried an erroneous date. The time was 1961, not 1971. In some copies, the article included a NASA biography's misspelling of his wife's given name. She is Suzan, not Susan.

results.abstract: Rev Jesse L Jackson and Rev Al Sharpton, who have conducted years-long tussle over who would lead modern civil rights movement, unite to promote Sen John Kerry for president; all three appear at Friendship Missionary Baptist Church in Miami, Fla, with Jackson and Sharpton preaching to congregation of black worshipers in critical state (M)

headline.main: Pair of Rivals Unite for Kerry, if Not Necessarily Each Other

results.snippet: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and the Rev. Al Sharpton stood side by side to preach the importance of voting for Senator John Kerry to black churchgoers in Florida.
results.lead_paragraph: George W. Bush campaigned in 2000 as ''a uniter, not a divider,'' but John Kerry brought evidence of his ability to join rival factions with him on Sunday to the Friendship Missionary Baptist Church here. Mr. Kerry walked to the altar flanked by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and the Rev. Al Sharpton, whose years-long tussle over who would march at the front of the modern civil rights movement had been simmering behind the scenes throughout this presidential campaign.

results.abstract: Arts, Briefly column; books by Austrian novelest Elfriede Jelinek jump in sales on Amazon.com after she wins Nobel Prize in literature; demand is so high for some books that American distributor, Consortium, sells out its stock; photo (S)
results.snippet: "The Piano Teacher" by Elfriede Jelinek, the winner of the Nobel Prize in literature, has sold out of its stock.
results.lead_paragraph: A Post-Nobel Roller Coaster Before the Austrian novelist ELFRIEDE JELINEK, right, won the Nobel Prize in literature on Thursday, her books were not exactly blockbusters. One of her best known works in English translation, ''The Piano Teacher'' -- a novel of lust and domination written in the biting style that, in the Swedish Academy's description, reveals ''the absurdity of society's clichés and their subjugating power'' -- was No. 1,163,804 on Amazon.com's sales rankings early Thursday, according to The Associated Press. By Friday, it had climbed to No. 9, one of four of Ms. Jelinek's works to reach the top 70. (By yesterday, however, her books had slipped a little; ''The Piano Teacher'' was No. 17 and two other titles, ''Wonderful, Wonderful Times'' and ''Women as Lovers,'' had fallen into the triple digits.) Demand has been so high for some of the books that the American distributor for Ms. Jelinek's work is sold out of its stock, and new copies will not arrive for three to four weeks. ''You don't keep a large quantity of books around when they're not moving,'' said SUSAN DOERR, the marketing director for the distributor, Consortium. 'Twas the Night Before... MICHAEL MOORE and the distributors of his documentary ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' are in talks to bring the film to pay-per-view television the night before the presidential election. The film would be part of a three-hour program to be broadcast on Nov. 1, which would also feature interviews with politically minded celebrities, according to reports from Reuters and Variety. Carried by In Demand Networks, the program, ''The Michael Moore Pre-Election Special,'' would begin at 8 p.m. Eastern Time the night before the election and cost $9.95. The DVD and VHS versions of Mr. Moore's film together sold about 2 million copies on Tuesday, the first day of their release, according to Sony. Pop: Albums in Release Fall is a big season for the music industry, a time when record labels look for major hits that will carry them for the rest of the year. Among the notable recordings -- and potential hits -- to be released tomorrow are ''Astronaut'' (Epic), the latest comeback vehicle for the 1980's pop group Duran Duran, led by SIMON LE BON, left, and its first album since the 80's to feature all the original members; ''The New Danger'' (Geffen), the first CD in five years by MOS DEF, the rapper and actor who was nominated for an Emmy Award this year; CELINE DION's ''Miracle'' (Epic); a solo album by FRANK BLACK, the Pixies' leader, ''Frank Black Francis'' (SpinART), a two-CD set featuring new and old versions of Pixies songs; the smart-alecky punk-pop group Sum 41's fourth album, ''Chuck'' (Island); and a small pile of Christmas albums (yes, leaves are barely turning, yet it's time for Christmas albums) by LEANN RIMES, the Trans-Siberian Orchestra, BIG BAD VOODOO DADDY, CHRIS ISAAK and VANESSA WILLIAMS. Uploaders, Beware Following the aggressive legal campaign of American record companies, the British Phonographic Industry (B.P.I.), the trade group that represents record labels in Britain, will begin to issue lawsuits to Internet users it says are illegally trading music. The B.P.I. announced late last week that it would sue 28 Internet users who were identified as ''major uploaders'' -- that is, those who make music available for others to download -- the BBC reported. The B.P.I. began its campaign in March by warning 350,000 users that they were illegally trading music. The B.P.I. does not yet know the names of the the users that it will target, but it is asking the British courts to force the users' Internet service providers to release their personal information. 'Shark Tale' No. 1 The animated comedy ''Shark Tale'' remained the top dog at the box office, taking in $31.7 million to hold the No. 1 spot for the second straight weekend, The Associated Press reported. ''Friday Night Lights,'' directed by PETER BERG and starring BILLY BOB THORNTON, took second place with $20.6 million, according to studio estimates Sunday. The film is based on the real-life fervor for high school football in Odessa, Texas. ''Shark Tale'' held up especially well, its haul down just 33 percent from opening weekend. The movie lifted its 10-day total to $87.7 million. ''Ladder 49'' was third with $13.3 million, and the QUEEN LATIFAH and JIMMY FALLON action comedy ''Taxi'' had a mediocre opening weekend of $12.05 million to place fourth. The weekend's other new wide release, ''Raise Your Voice'' with HILARY DUFF, opened No. 6 with $4.6 million. Footnotes TOMMY LEE, the bad-boy drummer for Mötley Crüe, will try out for the marching band at the University of Nebraska today. Mr. Lee is at the school for a reality television show in which he will live the life of an undergraduate, taking classes in chemistry, literature and the history of rock 'n' roll, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Lee, a high school dropout, told The Lincoln Journal Star that he was looking forward to ''a little music, some education, some partying -- the whole college experience.'' The school said it hopes the show will be a way for potential students to learn about college life, but faculty is bracing for the worst. ''I hope that turns out to be the right judgment,'' Chancellor Harvey Perlman wrote to faculty in an e-mail message last week. ''I am tempted to say something like, 'If it doesn't work you can vote me off the island,' but I've already used that line. All I can say is join me in keeping your fingers crossed.'' results.abstract: Maxime A Faget, pioneering aerospace engineer whose design of original Mercury space capsule ushered US into age of manned space flight, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline.main: Maxime Faget, 83; Pioneering Aerospace Engineer Designed Mercury Capsule

results.snippet: Maxime A. Faget's design of the Mercury capsule solved one of the thorniest problems of putting a man into space: how to protect the craft and its occupant from the hazards of re-entry.
results.lead_paragraph: Maxime A. Faget, a pioneering aerospace engineer whose design of the original Mercury space capsule ushered the United States into the age of manned space flight, died on Saturday at his home in Houston. He was 83. NASA announced the death, which came just five days after that of Gordon Cooper, one of the seven original Mercury astronauts.

results.abstract: Federal Aviation Administration bestows commercial astronaut wings on Brian Binnie, whose flight in SpaceShipOne won $10 million Ansari X Prize competition; only one other set of same wings, which are given to pilots who fly more than 50 miles above earth, has been issued to date to Michael W Melvill, who was first flyer of SpaceShipOne; drawing (M)

headline.main: Now Earning Wings, A New Kind of Astronaut

results.snippet: SpaceShipOne's pilot received a new honor: commercial astronaut wings awarded by the Federal Aviation Administration for those who fly more than 50 miles above Earth.
results.lead_paragraph: After SpaceShipOne won the $10 million Ansari X Prize competition last week, the man who took it into space, Brian Binnie, became the second person ever to receive a new kind of honor: commercial astronaut wings awarded by the Federal Aviation Administration for those who fly more than 50 miles above Earth. Michael W. Melvill, who flew the plane on its first two successful missions, in June and in September, is the only other person to receive the pin, which resembles those worn by spacefarers in NASA and the military. Only 434 people have left the planet in the four decades of the space age and can wear a version of what must be one of the very most enhancing accessories.

results.abstract: Replacement crew for International Space Station blasts off aboard Soyuz spacecraft from Baikonur Cosmodrome, Russia; American Leroy Chiao and Russian Salizhan Sharipov will relieve Gennady Padalka and NASA science officer Mike Finckea, who have been on station since Apr (S)

headline.main: Relief Crew Is on Its Way to Space Station

results.snippet: A replacement crew for the International Space Station blasted off aboard a Soyuz spacecraft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Russia.
results.lead_paragraph: A replacement crew for the International Space Station blasted off aboard a Soyuz spacecraft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Russia early today. The capsule will dock to the orbiting complex on Saturday.

results.abstract: Sam Lipsyte reviews book Tokyo Doesn't Love Us Anymore by Ray Loriga, translated by John King; photo (M)
results.snippet: The hero of this novel by the Spanish writer Ray Loriga sells a drug that provides instant amnesia.
results.lead_paragraph: TOKYO DOESN'T LOVE US ANYMORE By Ray Loriga. Translated by John King. 260 pp. Grove Press. Paper, $12.

headline.main: A New Crew Arrives At the Space Station

results.snippet: A Soyuz spacecraft with a replacement crew for the International Space Station docked safely with the orbiting complex.
results.lead_paragraph: A Soyuz spacecraft with a replacement crew for the International Space Station docked safely early on Saturday with the orbiting complex. Col. Salizhan S. Sharipov of the Russian Air Force performed the maneuver manually after the automatic rendezvous system failed during the final stages of the approach. Arriving for a six-month stay were Leroy Chiao, a NASA astronaut with a doctorate in chemical engineering who will take over next week as the station commander, and Colonel Sharipov, the station's flight engineer. They are relieving Gennady I. Padalka, a Russian Air Force colonel, and E. Michael Fincke, a United States Air Force lieutenant colonel, who have spent half a year in space.

results.abstract: Sen Kerry tries to shore up his macho bona fides among rural voters by going hunting for geese in Ohio, but National Rifle Assn continues its opposition to his candidacy; Vice Pres Cheney points to Kerry's poor rating from NRA; Kerry appears later with Dana Reeve, widow of Christopher Reeve, who endorsed him because of his support for embryonic stem-cell research; Kerry paints Bush as favoring ideology over science; photo (M)

headline.main: Kerry on Hunting Photo-Op to Help Image

results.snippet: Clad in camouflage clothing, a 12-gauge double-barreled shotgun under his arm, Senator John Kerry presented an image that his aides hope will help shore up his support among rural voters.
results.lead_paragraph: Clad in camouflage clothing, a 12-gauge double-barreled shotgun under his arm, Senator John Kerry and three fellow hunters emerged from an eastern Ohio cornfield Thursday morning with four dead geese and an image his aides hope will help shore up his macho bona fides among rural voters. ''Everybody got one, everybody got one,'' said Mr. Kerry, his hand stained with goose blood, though he was the only member of the hunting party not carrying a carcass.

results.abstract: Melanie Bush New York Observed article recalls Miss Subways contests, which ran from 1941 to 1977 and have been revived to celebrate subway system's 100th anniversary; visits Ellen's Stardust Diner, where Ellen Hart Strum, Miss Subways of March 1959, displays Miss Subways posters; photos (M)
results.snippet: For three decades, New York women had an icon of beauty that was ethnic, real and even covertly feminist. Now, she is set to reign again.
results.lead_paragraph: RIDING the D train to Sheepshead Bay in the 1970's, I knew I would never be Miss America. Not just because I was short, Jewish and nerdily bespectacled by the time I was 8. No, it was something more enigmatic than that, and even less changeable: Even as an 8-year-old, I sensed the complete and irrevocable impossibility of anyone who rode the D train ever becoming Miss America. Burdened -- tainted -- with intimate knowledge of the D train, I could never grow up into that ideal of disinterested equanimity all Miss Americas should embody. But so what? I could become Miss Subways.

headline.main: Two Safely Back After 6 Months on Space Station

results.snippet: Two astronauts who spent half a year aboard the International Space Station returned safely on Saturday to the steppes of Kazakhstan in the predawn darkness.
results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts who spent half a year aboard the International Space Station returned safely on Saturday to the steppes of Kazakhstan in the pre-dawn darkness. An American astronaut, Lt. Col. E. Michael Fincke, of the Air Force, and Col. Gennady I. Padalka, of the Russian Air Force landed aboard their Soyuz capsule at 6:36 a.m., three hours after separating from the orbital complex.

results.abstract: Article on likelihood that space tourism is possible in not-too-distant future now that SpaceShipOne, small three-person spacecraft designed by Burt Rutan and underwritten by Microsoft founder Paul Allen, has made three successful test flights into space; photo (M)
results.snippet: RICHARD GARRIOTT is ready to slip the surly bonds of earth. In the 1990's he put down a $10,000 deposit, not once but twice, with companies that promised to take him there. At the time, he said, it was more an act of faith than a purchase.     ''If...
results.lead_paragraph: RICHARD GARRIOTT is ready to slip the surly bonds of earth. In the 1990's he put down a $10,000 deposit, not once but twice, with companies that promised to take him there. At the time, he said, it was more an act of faith than a purchase. ''If you had asked me five years ago what I thought the probability was, I would have crossed my fingers and said 50-50,'' said Mr. Garriott, a multimillionaire computer-game designer from Austin, Tex., whose father, Owen K. Garriott, was an astronaut. ''If you asked me today, I would say 99 percent,'' he said, and within three to five years at that.

results.abstract: Benjamin Genocchio reviews Evidence Revisited, exhibition of anonymous, mostly black-and-white photographs selected from government and institutional archives which is on tour at Vassar College's Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center; photos (M)

headline.main: What Do These Pictures Mean? It's All in Your Imagination

results.snippet: THE fall season's most baffling exhibition has touched down at the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center here at Vassar College. ''Evidence,'' first exhibited with much controversy in San Francisco in 1977, consists of 89 anonymous black-and-white...
results.lead_paragraph: THE fall season's most baffling exhibition has touched down at the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center here at Vassar College. ''Evidence,'' first exhibited with much controversy in San Francisco in 1977, consists of 89 anonymous black-and-white photographs and a lone color picture selected from government and institutional archives by the artists Larry Sultan and Mike Mandel. Among these mysterious documentary images is a man with a fireproof plastic bag on his head (reminding you freakishly of the hooded figure in one of the photographs from Abu Ghraib) and another of someone doing push-ups on a carpeted floor in an astronaut suit. What could they mean? This is a difficult question, for there are no image captions. All we are told is that the artists spent two years searching for images in the files and archives of more than 100 government agencies, educational institutions and corporations ranging from the Highway Users Federation and Asphalt Institute to the Beverly Hills Police Department. Now a classic of conceptual photography, ''Evidence'' is being toured nationally by the Center for Creative Photography in Tucson, the archive to which the artists donated the prints.
